node.title: Proposal: New CSS selector engine for jsdom
node.body:
`nwsapi` has been working great so far, and I appreciate the developer's hard work, but `nwsapi` is unable to support Selectors Level 4 properly at the moment.
You can find many selector-related bug reports in the `jsdom` issues.

Therefore, I recommend changing to a different CSS selector engine [dom-selector](https://github.com/asamuzaK/domSelector).
It supports many features of the Selectors Level 4 and also the Shadow Hosts.
Ref [Supported CSS selectors](https://github.com/asamuzaK/domSelector#supported-css-selectors)

# Benchmark results

```
npm run benchmark
```

|API|nwsapi|dom-selector|
|:--------|:--------|:--------|
|closest()|jsdom x 126,133 ops/sec ±0.75% (73 runs sampled)|jsdom x 7,449 ops/sec ±13.28% (64 runs sampled)|
|matches()|jsdom x 120,369 ops/sec ±8.31% (65 runs sampled)|jsdom x 8,507 ops/sec ±7.84% (60 runs sampled)|
|querySelector()|jsdom x 3.12 ops/sec ±2.60% (12 runs sampled)|jsdom x 14.72 ops/sec ±1.94% (35 runs sampled)|
|querySelectorAll()|jsdom x 2.93 ops/sec ±1.52% (11 runs sampled)|jsdom x 12.41 ops/sec ±2.47% (31 runs sampled)|

For `closest()` and `matches()`, `nwsapi` is about 15 times faster, but in reality, `dom-selector` processed in 0.11 to 0.13 msec, so I don't think it's extremely slow.
Rather, it is `querySelector()` and `querySelectorAll()` that often have speed performance issues, and in this benchmark, `dom-selector` is about 4 times faster than `nwsapi`.

node.bodyText:
I noticed that the global window is accessible via document.defaultView.
So if dom-selector throws an exception like throw new document.defaultView.DOMException(), these try-catch can be completely removed, right?
Yes, that's right!

Thanks for the  quick reply.
I will rewrite the code and PR.

node.title: Add model for iCubGenova11
node.body:
The `iCubGenova11` is an iCub 2.7, so we generated the model accordingly.

It also fixes https://github.com/robotology/icub-models-generator/issues/255 to ensure that CI is green. I manually run the CI to push the generated files in https://github.com/robotology/icub-models/tree/addicubgenova11 for testing @martinaxgloria .

node.title: feat: improve footer
node.body: This PR aims at improving the footer of the website (navigation, logo, background of light theme). It is related to the issue #353 Still to be done : center the column -> help needed. ## Summary by CodeRabbit - **Documentation** - Updated the footer section with new links and sections for improved navigation and resource accessibility. - **Style** - Enhanced the footer's visual appeal with a new gradient background. - Improved the layout of the footer for better alignment and readability using flexbox properties.

node.title: 整理: 疑問形 upspeak の単純化
node.body:
## 内容
概要: 疑問形 upspeak 処理の単純化によるリファクタリング  

ネストの解消・処理の簡素化によってリファクタリングをおこなった。  

## 関連 Issue
part of #897

## Reviewer 向け情報
3つの関数ネストを削除したため、diff が機能していません。  
commit ごとに 1 つの関数を削除したため、レビュー時には commit log を参照していただければ幸いです。

node.bodyText:
この変更ですが、一般的には関数側にフラグを与えてどうするかを委ねるよりも、単一処理を行う関数にするのが良いとされていると思います。
ChatGPTに両者のメリットを聞いてみた感じ、この返答が自分の考えと近かったです。
https://chat.openai.com/share/cb0a7a43-fbff-4876-801a-921c90ed5618
何かこうしている意図があれば知りたいです！

一般的には ... 単一処理を行う関数にするのが良い

👍
一般論として同意です。

こうしている意図があれば

「upspeak 適用有無含めて 1 機能とみなし、厳密にテストできるから」が意図/理由です。
現在の test_synthesis_engine_base.py では spy に用いて .synthesis() の一部をテストしています。

  
    
      voicevox_engine/test/test_synthesis_engine_base.py
    
    
        Lines 214 to 218
      in
      831d28a
    
  
  
    

        
          
           self.synthesis_engine.synthesis( 
        

        
          
               query, 0, enable_interrogative_upspeak=enable_interrogative_upspeak 
        

        
          
           ) 
        

        
          
           # _synthesis_implの第一引数に与えられたqueryを検証 
        

        
          
           actual = self.synthesis_engine._synthesis_impl.call_args[0][0].accent_phrases 
        
    
  



  
    
      voicevox_engine/test/test_synthesis_engine_base.py
    
    
        Lines 255 to 259
      in
      831d28a
    
  
  
    

        
          
           self.create_synthesis_test_base( 
        

        
          
               text="これはありますか？", 
        

        
          
               expected=expected, 
        

        
          
               enable_interrogative_upspeak=False, 
        

        
          
           ) 
        
    
  


このテスト対象領域が「upspeak 適用有無 + upspeak適用」つまり今回切り出された apply_interrogative_upspeak() に相当するコードです。
現在のテストではこのコードを enable_interrogative_upspeak フラグ値を変えながら幅広いパターンでテストしています。この幅広さはupspeak有無のバグが品質に大きな影響を与えるためだと思われます。
#899 で議論されたように .synthesis() の入力設定全パターンテストは不可能です。
これが理由で、フラグを外に出すと現行の「enable_interrogative_upspeak フラグ値を変えながら幅広いパターン」を捨てることになります。
enable_interrogative_upspeak フラグを upspeak 量を調整する何かと見做してしまえば、apply_interrogative_upspeak() の引数に調整設定値が入るのはそこまで違和感無いと思います。
よって upspeak適用有無含めて 1 機能とみなすのは（少なくとも）おかしなことではなく、他のメリット・デメリットでフラグを引数にするか否か決めて良いことになります。
これら観点を総合した結果、適用有無含め1機能と見做して現行の幅広いテストを保持することが最善と考え、一般論とは異なる切り出し方をしています。
追記:
将来の方向性として、

#897 が進行して .synthesis() と ._synthesis_impl() が統合
query_to_decoder_feature() 内へ本 PR の apply_interrogative_upspeak() を移植
他の apply 関数達と並ぶ

を想定しています（下コードは最終状態のイメージ）
def query_to_decoder_feature(query) -> tuple[ndarray, ndarray]:
    accent_phrases = query.accent_phrases
    # 設定を適用する
    accent_phrases = apply_interrogative_upspeak(accent_phrases, query) # query内upspeakフラグ
    moras = apply_prepost_silence(to_flatten_moras(accent_phrases), query)
    moras = apply_speed_scale(moras, query)
    moras = apply_pitch_scale(moras, query)
    ...

なるほどです！！
少なくとも今のPRのapply_interrogative_upspeak関数は、queryクラス（つまり関数の責務範囲外）にenable_interrogative_upspeakがあることを想定しないべきだと思います。この関数だけ見た場合に、なぜこのフラグがあるのかわからないかなと。
queryそのものを渡す設計を予定しているのであれば話は別でした。いったんNOTEコメントが有ると良いのかなと！
コメントを追加してマージさせていただこうと思います！

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
                """必要に応じて各アクセント句の末尾へ疑問形モーラ（同一母音・継続長 0.15秒・音高↑）を付与する"""
          
          
            
                """必要に応じて各アクセント句の末尾へ疑問形モーラ（同一母音・継続長 0.15秒・音高↑）を付与する"""
          
          
            
                # NOTE: 将来的にAudioQueryインスタンスを引数にする予定
LGTM！！！

node.title: Kube-proxy/nftables: allow "numgen inc"
node.body:
This makes the nftables proxier distribute traffic in the same way as proxy-mode=ipvs with the "rr" scheduler


#### What type of PR is this?

/kind feature
/sig network
/area kube-proxy

#### What this PR does / why we need it:

Existing users of proxy-mode=ipvs may feel more comfortable if they can keep the round-robin distribution when upgrading to proxy-mode=nftables.

It should be noted that the same limitation applied for nftables with "random inc" as for ipvs/rr: the individual kube-proxy instances on the nodes are not coordinated, but distribute individually. And different schedulers are not possible, as in "ipvs".

#### Which issue(s) this PR fixes:

N/A

#### Special notes for your reviewer:

For start this is a PoC.

A more suitable name than `numgen` should probably be used in the proxier structure. Trying to look into the future, one might expect some new features in nftables, like maglev-hashing", and make it possible to configure those future things without altering the config API, just use a new value for some distribution parameter.

#### Does this PR introduce a user-facing change?

```release-note
Allow users to configure the distribution in proxy-mode=nftables to mimic proxy-mode=ipvs with round-robin
```

#### Additional documentation e.g., KEPs (Kubernetes Enhancement Proposals), usage docs, etc.:

node.bodyText: this is going to be a bit of bikeshedding, but random seems to be a better default since is the one used by cilium and kube-proxy iptables, that I are used more than ivps https://gist.github.com/aojea/5f82db3ba5f1efd59bb73f4b28614a6a

I kind of agree. Random is random, but people expect too much of other schedulers, even "rr". Like the endless discussion of "initial distribution", mentioned for instance in #121591 (comment). Even maglev-hashing doesn't work out-of-the-box in the way people expect.

No plan at the moment. I just read the nft doc's and saw that it can be done. Easily.
But I can't say I have any strong opinions about it, except that is may make some current users of ipvs more comfortable with the upgrade as mentioned in the description. But people may select ipvs for other reasons than "rr", e.g. get rid of the "probability chain" in iptables, that can look horrible for many endpoints, or simply that they know ipvs and it's easier to understand (my case). Or they want another scheduler, which can't be supported by nftables anyway.

I made some experiments of my own with K8s load-balancing, but without any http considerations, only plain tcp connects, at: https://github.com/uablrek/xcluster-ovls/tree/main/k8s-load-balancing
The hardest part was to create the table with Unix/Linux commands, please see:
https://github.com/uablrek/xcluster-ovls/blob/510cca913b632ae0a8506c45bf69d92bc1e6373e/k8s-load-balancing/k8s-load-balancing.sh#L72
But yes, my thought was a config option.

ChatGPT thinks IPTables proxy uses round-robbin algorithm, directing new requests to next destination in the list of pods.  Maybe that is what people think/expect in general - round-robin rather than random 🤔
https://chat.openai.com/share/20271990-883b-476b-b5b0-3c2d2b7efbaf

It should be configurable. For now random, round-robin and hash could be supported, https://wiki.nftables.org/wiki-nftables/index.php/Load_balancing. I think someone out there is already implementing maglev-hashing. But it may be a good idea to keep it simple, and just do random. After all, it has worked fine for the vast majority of K8s users.
I advocate for trying to keep the same behavior as in iptables, but @danwinship is leading this feature, let's see what he thinks

node.title: Add support for `CollapsedDocStrings` in `@meta` block
node.body:
Setting `DocStringsCollapsed = true` in the `@meta` block of a particular page essentially clicks the "Collapse all docstrings" in the navigation bar after the page loads, collapsing all docstrings on that page.

I think the approach of just having JavaScript click the collapse button is the right one here: First, I'm not sure that it would be possible to write out the page in a collapsed state, or at least not without doing some pretty gnarly rewrites of the `HTMLWriter`. More importantly, rendering the page expanded and then collapsing it with JavaScript seems like the right thing to do from an accessibility standpoint: We'd want the page to still be useful without JavaScript. I've been known to access API documentation in the terminal with `w3m`, so not relying on JavaScript to render the core content is something I actually care about. Screenreaders probably also wouldn't like if all docstrings initially rendered as `hidden`.

Closes #2282

node.bodyText:
I feel that ideally we'd do this by statically generating the necessary HTML. It looks like we use display: none on the section tags.. and then update some other stuff. Ideally, we'd have a class on the article tag that toggles everything.
How much effort would you be willing to put into this? I didn't test this yet, but I assume that this works, and we can merge this as is, and refactor later as well.

More importantly, rendering the page expanded and then collapsing it with JavaScript seems like the right thing to do from an accessibility standpoint: We'd want the page to still be useful without JavaScript.

Ah.. that is a fair point actually. We should indeed make sure that it loads uncollapsed if you don't have JS enabled. So now I'm coming around to this approach.

Right. I'd still advocate for going with the approach in this PR. I started out with trying to write out the collapsed HTML if the option is set until I realized that:
(a) It's much more difficult to implement that way. In fact, I'm not sure that I'd be able to do it in any reasonable amount of time.
(b) "Collapsed" means display: none, which removes the content entirely without JS, which seems like a bad idea.
The test in the PR only checks for the presence of the injected JS. I don't think there's much I can do beyond that. I did test locally that the JS does what it's supposed to (very nicely, in fact). What I could do as an additional test is to use the feature in the Documenter documentation. Maybe collapsing all the Internal API pages by default?

Yeah, let's go with the JS approach.
It currently does have the problem that you can see all the docstrings collapsing when you navigate to the page though. Maybe @Hetarth02 has some ideas how to work around that.
Interesting, I will definitely take a look into this.

@Hetarth02 I'd appreciate that! You might be better at JS than me. I'm having real trouble getting it to load correctly. In my first iteration, it worked fine locally but only 90% of the time in Chrome and only 1% of the time in Safari. I'm guessing the script was running too early. In the current iteration, I've tried to move the <script> tag to the end of the file, but that's still behaving the same way (i.e., not working in Safari). I also tried putting it in an external script (I think local scripts load before external scripts, which may be part of the problem), but that was much more complicated to implement, and then just didn't work at all. I can push that branch again somewhere if you'd like to take a look at it.

It currently does have the problem that you can see all the docstrings collapsing when you navigate to the page though

Yeah, I can't decide whether it's a problem or whether I actually kinda like it. But in any case, I think jQuery is handling the collapse animation. Maybe there's a way to temporarily disable the animation or at least speed it up?

Yes, Jquery handles the animation and there is a way to speed it up.
I also think that, initially appearing as open then getting closed is okay.

I can push that branch again

Pushed to https://github.com/JuliaDocs/Documenter.jl/tree/mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed2. This one doesn't work at all, though, and I'm not sure why.

I'm somewhat out of my depth when it comes to JS. Does anything from the discussion I had with ChatGPT seem useful here? https://chat.openai.com/share/a5c0b599-79f0-46e5-9840-74984896d398
The suggestion

Modify documenter.js to dispatch a custom event when it has fully loaded and executed. Then, in your script at the end of the page, add an event listener for this custom event before executing your code.

doesn't sound entirely implausible.

@goerz Which branch should I check from?
mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed2 or mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed

Preferably, mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed. The other one was an attempt to put the JS in a separate script file. It was both more complicated and didn't actually work, but I just wanted to keep the branch around in case mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed doesn't work out and I need to get back to it.

mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed works perfectly when looking at documentation locally with LiveServer, but doesn't work reliably when looking at the online documentation, e.g. at https://documenter.juliadocs.org/previews/PR2394/lib/internals/anchors/. In Chrome, it works most of the time, in Safari, it does not work most of the time. Presumably, the issue is the asynchronous execution of JS and the code that clicks the collapse button firing too early.
That sounds good! Do you want to just push to the mg/meta-docstrings-collapsed branch? I'm assuming you have permissions – or make a new branch, if you prefer.
I don't think I have the necessary permissions to do so.
I can merge from https://github.com/Hetarth02/Documenter.jl/ into my PR then. Let me know which branch.
Alright, will do so. Let me iron some things out and will ping you when I am done.
@goerz Sorry for the delay, I have pushed the changes to Draft-PR-2394. Also, made an PR to this branch.
No worries! Thanks for taking a look! I'll check it out.
@goerz Just FYI, this is just a rudimentary implementation from my side. There is of course room for improvement in logic.😅
It works perfectly! Thanks for coming up with the approach that makes this reliable!

This seems fine to me. It still shows the close-animation after the page is loaded. I don't mind it that much, but @mortenpi might still prefer if we speed it up.
@Hetarth02 Do you know what to add to control the animation speed?
Seems a little unrelated to the PR, but I just kept it in
Marked as "experimental" so we can still change this even after the PR is merged/released. For example, #2394 (comment)

I think I figured it out: e5b84d3
The currently deployed preview documentation disables the animation completely. Better? I'm okay with either.
This whole thing probably needs to be in a $(document).ready(function () { ... }?
Let's try it! https://documenter.juliadocs.org/previews/PR2394/ should now have that change. Of course, all I can say is that it continues to work for me, so you'll have to let us know :-)

Eh, yea, let's just keep it on the top-level. Doing namespacing adds other kinds of complexity. Some of these options will just be ignored by some backends.
  
    
      
        Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            - `DocStringsCollapsed`: if `true`, collapse all docstrings after loading the page (experimental).
          
          
            
            - `DocStringsCollapsed`: for output formats that support this (i.e. only [`HTML`](@ref Documenter.HTML) currently), if set to `true`, render all docstrings as collapsed by default.
@goerz I took the liberty of pushing a DocStringsCollapsed -> CollapsedDocString bikeshed. Happy to revert it if you prefer DocStringsCollapsed. From my side, I'm happy if we merge this!

node.title: airbyte-lib: Add telemetry
node.body:
This PR adds tracking to airbyte-lib.

On start of each sync, an event is sent to segment, tracking the date, the used source, cache and airbyte-lib version.
Once the sync finishes, a second event is sent, tracking whether the sync was successful or not.

This is done using basic http requests.

If the `DO_NOT_TRACK` env variable is set, no tracking events are sent.

This PR also sets the user agent for the connector registry json file request to make it possible to identify airbyte-lib requests.

node.bodyText:
Totally optional, but a common convention in Python if you want to call out that the intentional dropping of a return value - you can use "_ = ..."
This isn't necessary by any means, but will inform the reader "yes, I know there's a return value and no, I don't want to use it." 😄
  
    
      
        Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
                # Do not handle the response, we don't want to block the execution
          
          
            
                requests.post("https://api.segment.io/v1/track", auth=(TRACKING_KEY, ""), json=payload)
          
          
            
                # Do not handle the response, we don't want to block the execution
          
          
            
                _ = requests.post("https://api.segment.io/v1/track", auth=(TRACKING_KEY, ""), json=payload)
It's not clear to me what 'target' means in this context. Can we add a docstring to explain it?
Ditto above. I'm not sure what 'target' means here.

This might be a nit and/or semantic distinction, but I slightly prefer a name like get_telemetry_info or get_telemetry_markers over get_tracking_info. The work 'tracking', to me at least, implies ability to 'track' personally, to perhaps identify or de-anonymize, which this isn't doing.

Makes sense to me, I pondered the name a bit. Telemetry has the risk to be confused with telemetry in the sense of OpenTelemetry and the like, but it's probably better than tracking. "analytics" would be another option, but thinking about it calling this kind of thing telemetry is probably an industry standard for software running on the client.
It's about where the data is loaded to - a cache or streamed directly via iterable.

@flash1293 - Thanks for moving this forward! I've added several suggestions, but none need to block this increment. I'm approving with the noted suggestions, and we can follow-up in subsequent iterations if needed.
Not a blocker, but what happens if we omit ip altogether?

Not a blocker, but should we add a "suppress error" block here for any network issues or host availability issues? We wouldn't want those to cause a crash.
In some environments, only specific network endpoints are whitelisted, for instance - and this will (and should) fail if network access is not available to our telemetry endpoint.
I think we want the telemetry to fail gracefully/silently, so functionality is not affected.
For my info, what does this tracking key represent?

Since in-memory is out of scope for now, what do you think of the cache types just being the name of the DB backed? So, something like DUCKDB, POSTGRES, SNOWFLAKE, etc.? Or do you have something else in mind for this?

A nit, but could we rename this to source_info just to clarify it is not the original source object?
For context, when reading through, I panicked for a sec when I thought asdict(source) might contain the original source config and creds - and then relaxed on scrolling up to see the type was SourceTelemetryInfo. A slight rename to source_info or similar would just make this line more clear, since we use source elsewhere for the Source class instances.
(Edit: To clarify, I have no problem with the telemetry object schema having it's node called "source". Just the object on the right side is what I meant.)

This test is great. I think it also would be good to add a test that blocks network access, as mentioned above, to ensure that inability to reach the endpoint doesn't hang or crash the program.
I haven't done this myself but a quick ChatGPT session proposed code something like this:
import socket
import pytest
from unittest.mock import patch

# This function will replace socket.socket.connect
def block_network(*args, **kwargs):
    raise OSError("Network access not allowed during test")

# Use the patch decorator to replace socket.socket.connect with block_network
@patch('socket.socket.connect', new=block_network)
def test_telemetry_no_network():
    # Our test code here should call the tracking function and just
    # make sure that the OSError is caught and handled internally, aka _not_ raised.
I don't think we need to block this PR on the above, but I think we should track a follow-on action if not in scope for this iteration.

Something like this using contextlib.suppress, I think:
  
    
      
        Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
                # Do not handle the response, we don't want to block the execution
          
          
            
                _ = requests.post("https://api.segment.io/v1/track", auth=(TRACKING_KEY, ""), json=payload)
          
          
            
                # Suppress exceptions if host is unreachable or network is unavailable
          
          
            
                with suppress(OSError):  # Network errors are subclasses of `OSError`
          
          
            
                    # Do not handle the response, we don't want to block the execution
          
          
            
                    _ = requests.post("https://api.segment.io/v1/track", auth=(TRACKING_KEY, ""), json=payload)

I think we should use a context manager for this override, to prevent bleeding to other tests:
Something like this:
    with patch.dict('os.environ', {'DO_NOT_TRACK': ''}):
        # Our test code here
        # Within this block, 'DO_NOT_TRACK' is set to ''
        # Other environment variables are kept
Or if we want DO_NOT_TRACK to be unset, then maybe something like this:
    with patch.dict('os.environ', values={}, remove=['DO_NOT_TRACK']):
        # Our test code here
        # Within this block, 'DO_NOT_TRACK' is unset
        # Other environment variables are kept
I also think we should be clear about whether an empty string still counts as the variable being 'set'. I think this implementation would treat the empty string as 'unset', which makes sense I think. In the implementation files, I was originally going to recommend checking for "DO_NOT_CHECK" not in os.environ but that check would not work if we want the empty string to count as not being set.
I'm totally okay with either approach. Just calling out the distinction to make sure we're not missing anything.

I think I'd like to request one more attribute here, which is capturing the presence of a "CI" flag in os.environ.
CI tests are very noisy on our metrics - with the possibility to make up 50-80% of usage stats in some extreme cases, or in specific cross-sections of usage. Luckily, the industry has a convention:
https://chat.openai.com/share/eb500944-8bb6-43a1-b64e-5f901f4587c4
(Turns out "CI environment variable" is hard to google. I've previously seen a third party site advocating for this standard but I couldn't find it today so the above link is a ChatGPT conversation.)
Rather than return the value stored in the "CI" environment variable, I think it is sufficient to list it in 'extra_flags' or similar, or just as its own boolean ("True" means present").
Wdyt?

Even though it wouldn't contain much, we could also adopt the "TelemetryInfo" convention to be parallel with the source side. In that case, this would be a "CacheTelemetryInfo" dataclass, perhaps just with one member, and would render as a dict instead of a string in the telemetry object.

After giving this some more thought and research, I think I'm in the camp of the empty string being 'falsey' (tracking enabled) and any other set value being 'truthy' (meaning opted-out) - which is exactly how you have it now. This is easy to document and communicate, easy to modify, and unlikely to lead to any users thinking they are opted out when they actually aren't.
then segment would automatically add back the actual IP
Great suggestion!

Since in-memory is out of scope for now, what do you think of the cache types just being the name of the DB backed? So, something like DUCKDB, POSTGRES, SNOWFLAKE, etc

Yes, that's what the TODO on top is meant for.

Even though it wouldn't contain much, we could also adopt the "TelemetryInfo" convention to be parallel with the source side. In that case, this would be a "CacheTelemetryInfo" dataclass, perhaps just with one member, and would render as a dict instead of a string in the telemetry object.

Good suggestion, I will adjust it like that - maybe we want to add other dimensions later on.
Good suggestion, added a test for this (I made it part of the same block via a new parameter tuple.

Good suggestion to use patch.dict here!
Agreed, it depends on the nature of the environment variable, but for something like do_not_track it feels right to err on the side of interpreting something as truthy even if it wasn't meant like that - better than the other way around.

node.title: [Configs] Add foundation for RelayMiner operation configs.
node.body:
## Summary

### Human Summary

* Implement new `RlayMiner` configuration (#246) parser
* Adapt `RelayMiner` server initialization to
  * Source from the config
  * Check if the config matches the on-chain `Supplier`'s data
  * Support multiple proxy server instances 
* Adapt the `RelayMiner` config parser tests
* Adapt the `RelayMiner` unit tests

This PR is based on #257 and deprecates the `RelayMiner` part of it.

## Issue

- #274
- #271

## Type of change

Select one or more:

- [x] New feature, functionality or library
- [ ] Bug fix
- [ ] Code health or cleanup
- [ ] Documentation
- [ ] Other (specify)

## Testing

- [x] **Run all unit tests**: `make go_develop_and_test`
- [ ] **Run E2E tests locally**: `make test_e2e`
- [ ] **Run E2E tests on DevNet**: Add the `devnet-test-e2e` label to the PR. This is VERY expensive, only do it after all the reviews are complete.

## Sanity Checklist

- [x] I have tested my changes using the available tooling
- [x] I have performed a self-review of my own code
- [ ] I have commented my code, updated documentation and left TODOs throughout the codebase

The main reasons I see are

The service staked for may contain multiple endpoints (eg. to handle geolocated requests) and we must handle this scenario.
That the operator may want to route the requests coming from these domains to a single proxy
Migrating to a new domain, where requests may still arrive from the old one
Having internal requests coming from non FQDNs because of complex routing and debugging purposes.
